name: Islamic Center of Southern California
mission: THE ISLAMIC CENTER OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA IS AN INDEPENDENT ORGANIZATION. ITS PURPOSE IS TO PRACTICE AND SHARE THE VALUES OF ISLAM IN THE UNITED STATES ...
zakatClaimEvidence: The Islamic Center of Southern California (ICSC) explicitly mentions "Zakat & Sadaqah – Fulfill your religious obligations and assist those in need within our community" under its 'Ways to Give' section. Furthermore, it has a dedicated 'Zakat Program' that "offers crucial support including $15 food coupons, rental assistance, and utility assistance to help alleviate immediate needs". The ICSC's donation page also lists "Zakat al-Fitr" and "Zakat al-Mal" as specific donation categories. (Source: https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQEcbVWaxZpWjtyTy3jiV-1Vr_Lsq_ady9PujulHZYifVGezgk7GN3_arJjtKi2PZ-5JA47WELsJs_Mgs_pI_CXEE1jdpwsf5WDtPjREJhkd2VRo23SbtiHpv7B0)

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The overall score of 32/100 reflects a balance between the organization's long-standing community presence and financial metrics that indicate high overhead costs and limited transparent impact data.
areas_for_improvement: The program expense ratio of 49.6% suggests that a significant portion of funds is directed toward administrative or non-programmatic costs [2].
Limited external data and third-party verification contribute to a lower data confidence level [1].

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 29/50, the Center shows a medium fit for Muslim donors due to its Zakat-eligible status and religious-cultural urgency [4]. However, the overall score is tempered by the need for more comprehensive reporting on programmatic effectiveness beyond basic service provision [1][3].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization's impact score of 10/50 is categorized as capacity building, focusing on maintaining community infrastructure such as funeral services and educational programs [3]. While the Center maintains a healthy working capital of 17.2 months, the program expense ratio is 49.6%, and there is a lack of third-party evidence regarding specific cost-per-beneficiary outcomes [1][2].

strengths.detail: The Center maintains <cite id="8">17.2 months of working capital</cite>, providing a significant buffer against economic volatility.
The organization spends <cite id="6">$0.00 to raise every $1</cite> in contributions, ensuring donor acquisition costs do not deplete resources.

strengths_deep_dive: The Islamic Center of Southern California's greatest operational strength lies in its liquidity and financial independence. With <cite id="8">17.2 months of working capital held in working capital</cite>, the organization is better positioned than many peers to survive funding gaps. Furthermore, its governance structure is characterized by <cite id="11">100% independent board members</cite>, which supports objective oversight of its <cite id="12">$3,369,879 in total assets</cite>. This financial foundation supports a wide array of community-centric services, from <cite id="3">Sunday school education to funeral services</cite>, making it a central pillar of the Southern California Muslim community.
rich_narrative.summary: The Islamic Center of Southern California (ICSC) operates as an independent religious and social hub, dedicated to practicing and sharing Islamic values within the United States. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization managed <cite id="1">$2,134,893 in total revenue</cite>, primarily driven by <cite id="2">$2,111,995 in public contributions</cite>. Its service model focuses on community capacity building through a diverse range of programs, including a <cite id="3">food pantry, Sunday school, and funeral services</cite>. While the Center maintains a long-standing presence in the region, its financial profile shows a <cite id="4">program expense ratio of 49.6%</cite>, which is notably lower than the <cite id="5">peer program ratio median of 80.0%</cite> for similar religious and cultural organizations. Despite this, the Center demonstrates exceptional fiscal prudence in its development efforts, maintaining <cite id="6">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>. The organization also provides critical social infrastructure through its <cite id="7">Muslim Youth Group (MYG) and marriage services</cite>, ensuring a comprehensive support system for its constituents.
